elements.text: For this activity, you will need 10 Connecting Cubes for each child.
we saw that Lola planted seeds in many rows.
In this activity, you will use Connecting Cubes as “seeds.” You will plant the seeds in equal rows. Then, you will practice counting the seeds you’ve planted.
Give each child eight Connecting Cubes to start. Say,
Let’s plant two rows of seeds. Make sure both rows have the same amount of seeds!
Guide children to set the Connecting Cubes on the table in two rows of four.
Ask children to count the “seeds” in each row they have planted.
Let’s make sure each row has the same amount of seeds.
Guide children to count each row twice.
If we count the seeds in this order, are there still four seeds? Do both rows have the same number of seeds? How can you tell?
Have children create a pile with their cubes. Give each child two more cubes so that they have 10 to plant. Repeat the activity, asking children to plant the 10 seeds in two rows.
How do you plant seeds in two equal rows? How could you tell whether the two rows had the same amount of seeds?
Start with four Connecting Cubes, then increase to six. Model separating Connecting Cubes into two groups, and count aloud as you touch each “seed” to make sure the groups are equal.
Challenge children to separate their “seeds” into more than two groups: four groups of two (eight total); three groups of two (six total); five groups of two (10 total).
. Hold up two fingers on each hand to demonstrate the meaning of
Create “gardens” on the floor using masking tape. Have children plant their rows of seeds within their own “garden.” Have children clap as they count the seeds in each row.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
For this activity, you will need enough blue and green Pattern Blocks so that every child has five of each color.
we talked about why it is important to make plans for a garden or another project. We also talked about the patterns we saw in the pictures.
In this activity, you will make a plan to create a garden for someone you care about. You will pretend that the blue and green Pattern Blocks are flowers that you will plant.
Place blue and green Pattern Blocks on the table. Ask children one at a time to count out five green blocks and then five blue blocks.
Do you have five green blocks? How many blue blocks? Even though the Pattern Blocks look different, are the amounts the same?
Guide children to create an ABAB pattern using the green and blue pattern blocks.
Let’s plan our garden with a pattern! We can start with a green flower, then a blue flower, then green, then blue. What color flower comes next?
Continue until all 10 Pattern Blocks have been used.
If time allows, have children count out five yellow blocks. Repeat the activity, this time with an ABC pattern (yellow, green, blue, yellow, green, blue).
Congratulate children on their plans, and discuss ways to show caring for others.
How can planting a garden show someone that you care about them? Who would you like to plant a garden for?
Model counting out five Pattern Blocks of each color from the pile, counting aloud one at a time. Create the ABAB pattern yourself, then encourage children to copy it.

Invite children to create their own garden patterns using as many Pattern Blocks as they like. Ask them what pattern they plan to make before they start planting. Then, after they create the pattern, ask children to tell whether their pattern matches the one they described.
as well as color names before beginning. Model each step of the activity and have children complete one step before proceeding to the next. Narrate what children are doing as they work.

Instead of using Pattern Blocks, have children use colored pencils to draw flower patterns. Encourage children to add detail to the garden, and invite them to take the drawings home to show their family and friends.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
For this activity, you will need to create a 5-frame out of tape or string on the table and five Connecting Cubes for each child.
we saw that Lola planted seeds that grew into flowers.

In this activity, you will use Connecting Cubes as “seeds” to plant a garden. I will ask you to plant a certain number of seeds. Then you will tell me how many seeds are in the garden and how many seeds you have left to plant.
Point out the 5-frame “garden” on the table. Give each child five Connecting Cubes to use as “seeds.” Place one Connecting Cube in the “garden.”
I’ve planted one seed to start.
Ask a child to plant two seeds in the garden. Ask,
How many seeds are in the garden now?
Guide the child to add the two new seeds to the seed you planted. Then ask,
How many seeds do you have left to plant?
Guide the child to count the two unplanted seeds.

Clear the 5-frame and ask another child to plant a different number of seeds. Ask the child to tell you how many seeds are in the garden and how many seeds the child has left to plant. Continue the activity until all children have had at least one turn.
Are seeds taller or shorter than plants? Imagine that the Connecting Cubes you planted today were real seeds. What kind of plant would you want to grow? How tall will these plants be?

Have each child start with three Connecting Cubes. Model beginning with two seeds in your own hand, and one in the garden. Plant one seed then think aloud as you add two more seeds. Once children become proficient with three seeds, add one or two more.
Place 10 Connecting Cubes in the garden to begin. Challenge children to remove seeds from the garden.
There are too many seeds in the garden! Take one out. How many seeds are in the garden now? How many do you have left to plant?
plant, garden, seeds, have left to plant
. Using Numeral Cards, encourage children to point to the number of seeds in the garden and the number of seeds they have left.

Use Connecting Cubes of the same color so that children who may have difficulty processing color will not be distracted from counting. Provide gloves for children who have trouble touching the Connecting Cubes with their bare hands.
. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
For this activity, you will need Connecting Cubes.
we talked about how very, very tall the beanstalk was!

In this activity, you will each build a beanstalk using Connecting Cubes in a pattern. You will build your beanstalk as high as you can! Then, we will count the number of Connecting Cubes you used to compare the heights of your beanstalks.
Give each child a different number of Connecting Cubes, equally split between two colors. For example, give one child three green and three blue cubes, one child four red and four orange cubes, etc.
Guide children to build a beanstalk using an ABAB pattern of Connecting Cubes.
Let’s build our beanstalks as tall as we can! Let’s start with one color and then use the other color. What color will come next? Show me!
Once children have built their beanstalks as high as possible, invite them to place their beanstalks side by side to compare.
Which beanstalk is the tallest? Which is the shortest?
Guide children to count the number of Connecting Cubes in each beanstalk to discuss height. For example,
This beanstalk is six Connecting Cubes tall. This one is 10. It is taller.
How could you tell which beanstalk was the tallest? How many cubes tall was the shortest beanstalk?

Create a “beanstalk” using the ABAB pattern, and have children copy it. Give half of the group two Connecting Cubes in two colors, and the other half three cubes in two colors. Have children compare “beanstalks” and decide which are “tall” and which are “short.”
Add a Connecting Cube of a third color, and invite children to create their own pattern using all three colors. Challenge children to place the “beanstalks” in order from tallest to shortest.
. Encourage children to point to the “beanstalk” that is tallest, and hold up the number of fingers to show how many cubes tall each beanstalk is.
Have children build their beanstalks in separate areas of the room. When all children have finished building, invite them to bring their beanstalks together to one table to compare their heights.
